com.sri.ai.grinder.sgdpllt.theory.base

Class SingleVariableConstraintForTheoryWithoutAtoms

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.sri.ai.grinder.core.AbstractExpression
      • com.sri.ai.expresso.helper.AbstractExpressionWrapper
        • com.sri.ai.grinder.sgdpllt.core.constraint.AbstractConstraint
          • com.sri.ai.grinder.sgdpllt.core.constraint.AbstractSingleVariableConstraint
            • com.sri.ai.grinder.sgdpllt.theory.base.SingleVariableConstraintForTheoryWithoutAtoms
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Expression, Constraint, SingleVariableConstraint, Serializable, Cloneable, Comparable<Object>

    @Beta
public class SingleVariableConstraintForTheoryWithoutAtoms
extends AbstractSingleVariableConstraint
    An implementation of SingleVariableConstraint for theories that define no atoms.

    Theories may have no atoms if they rely on translating their problems into some other theory. In those cases, there is no need to split on atoms or to keep single-variable constraints.

    Author:
    braz
    See Also:
    Serialized Form

      • fromNormalizedAtomToItsNegationAsLiteral

        public Expression fromNormalizedAtomToItsNegationAsLiteral(Expression normalizedAtom)
        Description copied from class: AbstractSingleVariableConstraint
        Returns the literal corresponding to the negation of the given normalized atom. Typically this will just return the application of NOT to the atom, but some languages may have more conventional (and more pleasing to read) ways of representing these negations (for example, not(X = a) -> X != a).
        Specified by:
        fromNormalizedAtomToItsNegationAsLiteral in class AbstractSingleVariableConstraint
        Returns:

      • destructiveUpdateOrNullAfterConjoiningNewNormalizedAtom

        public AbstractSingleVariableConstraint destructiveUpdateOrNullAfterConjoiningNewNormalizedAtom(boolean sign,
                                                                                                Expression atom,
                                                                                                Context context)
        Description copied from class: AbstractSingleVariableConstraint
        Extending classes define this method to perform whatever checks are needed after a new atom has been inserted, returning null in case of a detected contradiction or this object, or a simplified version of it, otherwise.

        In general, this will contain whatever theory-specific checks and simplifications that go beyond simple contradiction between normalized atoms.

        One example of this method being useful is in equality theory with finite domains. If a variable is constrained to be disequal to n distinct values and its type size is equal or less than n, we know the constraint is unsatisfiable. Because AbstractSingleVariableConstraint knows nothing about equalities, it will not detect that. An extension defining equality constraints can define this method to perform such check.

        Specified by:
        destructiveUpdateOrNullAfterConjoiningNewNormalizedAtom in class AbstractSingleVariableConstraint
        Returns:
